plants.name: Cactus Soil
plants.description: The Cactus Soil is a specialized soil mix for your cactus and succulent plants. It is made of a blend of well-draining materials to prevent overwatering. The soil is available in various bag sizes.
plants.care: N/A

plants.name: Fiddle Leaf Fig Set
plants.description: The Fiddle Leaf Fig Set includes three Fiddle Leaf Fig plants of different sizes, perfect for creating a dramatic focal point in your home. The set includes one small, one medium, and one large Fiddle Leaf Fig plant.
plants.care: Fiddle Leaf Figs require bright, indirect light to thrive. They prefer well-draining soil and should be watered when the top inch of soil feels dry. Avoid overwatering as it can lead to root rot. Fiddle Leaf Figs benefit from regular misting to increase humidity. Fertilize every 2-4 weeks during the growing season with a balanced houseplant fertilizer.

plants.name: Snake Plant
plants.description: Snake Plant, also known as Sansevieria, is a popular houseplant known for its upright, sword-like leaves. It is native to West Africa and is easy to care for, making it a great choice for beginners.
plants.care: Snake Plants prefer bright, indirect light but can tolerate low light conditions. They are drought-tolerant and should be watered sparingly, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. Snake Plants are also known for their air-purifying qualities. Fertilize every 2-3 months during the growing season with a balanced houseplant fertilizer.

plants.name: Pothos

plants.name: Aglaonema
plants.description: Aglaonema is a genus of evergreen herbs and shrubs of the Aroid family, or Araceae, originating from Southeast Asia. It is no coincidence that aglanonema is named after 'wealth'. This particular plant will make everyone stop to immerse themselves in its rich leaves. She looks like a living work of art; each leaf has a burst of color in shades of green and yellow in a dizzying pattern. You won't be able to take your eyes off her!
plants.care: Aglaonema needs little water, but it is important that the substrate remains moist. The substrate may be dry between waterings. Too much water can cause root rot. Aglaonema can be placed in many locations, but not in direct sunlight. Fertilize regularly with PLNTS organic fertilizer in spring and summer during the growth phase.
